Posts.Content: You know--you are human--do not be ashamed to be scared out of your mind.  So what if you cry like a baby.  We cannot always be a tower of strength, although often times we women think we need to be.  When I was first diagnosed in July 04, I wouldn't let ANYBODY say the "C-word" around me.  Now I talk about it all the time.  I am called the mammogram nazi since I am such an advocate.  The hysteria is all part of the process.  But you will come out stronger, better, more appreciative of life and all you know.  You will be enthralled with every day that you have life.  Sometimes I think having breast cancer just might have benn the best thing to happen to me.  There is no "wake-up call" like it.  So just let your emotions flow--it is part of the healing and dealing.  I love this quote: Courage is being scared to death...and saddling up anyway. (John Wayne).
Posts.Title: Trying Not to be Concerned!

Posts.Content: I find all this very interesting because we always hear about doctors over treating and ordering tests that probably aren't necessary--but insurance pays and some docs just want to make money.  So, your experience of being so insistent that tests be performed--well, you would think that some medical people would say. .. Oh, yeah, let's go ahead--thinking that some income would be generated.  I almost hate to suggest this because I like to think only the best of the docs that take care of us, but I wonder if they notice something about your insurance limitations and that might be a reason to not respond to your requests.  Just a thought--one that I certainly hope proves incorrect!
Posts.Title: Worried Misfiagnosis!

Posts.Content: This is indeed a very grave situation.  But everyone's body is different and resonds in different ways.  Being hopeful is very "good medicine."  Be there for your friend in whatever ways she needs.  Often just your silent companionship can be comforting.  She is going to go down a very rough road indeed.  I want to share a few quotes with you that you might write in a card:  Courage is being scared to death and saddling up anyway (John Wayne). Courage doesn't always roar.  Sometimes courage is the little voice at the end of the day that says I'll try again tomorrow. The I in illness is isolation, and the crucial letters in wellness are WE. There is in every true woman's heart a spark of heavenly fire which kindles up and beams and blazes in the dark hour of adversity.
Posts.Title: Need Information

Posts.Content: Hey, dear girl, you have lots of SISTERS through this site who will support you however we can.  Bad news can knock us down so flat that we think we might never get up.  But the human spirit is SO amazing.  You just keep up the fight.  Each day is progress.  Embrace the times you really FEEL good. I want to share with you a few of my favorite quotes: Courage is being scared to death--and saddling up anyway. (John Wayne) Hope is the companion of power, and the mother of success; for who so hopes strongly has within him the gift of miracles. (S. Smiles) You gain strength, courage and confidence by every experience in which you really stop to look fear in the face. You are able to say to yourself, "I lived through this horror. I can take the next thing that comes along." . . . You must do the thing you think you cannot do. — Eleanor Roosevelt
Posts.Title: stg 4/reaccurance b.c. in abdomen now

Posts.Content: I am thrilled to report that I am going to be taking my last tomaxifen in mid- August.  With family and firends we are having a PINK PARTY and I will take that last pill served on a silver platter and down it with pink champagne; everyone is going to wer pink--I am SO excited.  But--on to my questions.  I have read things here and there that soy is a No-No for breast cancer gals.  How dangerous is it to use soy?  I have put whey protein in my morning oatmeal for a couple of years, but it seems I may be having some difficulties eating so much dairy.  So, I have wondered if it would be dangerous to use soy protein instead of whey.  I use the protein powder because I am not much of a meat eater.  Also, what about body lotions containing soy (that certainly has become a trend).  Finally, what about soy "milk" like SILK?  Any nutritionists out there that can help with this?
Posts.Title: SOY and breast cancer

Posts.Content: I am so sorry about the stress you and your daughter are going through---plus the whole cheerleading squad!  Hope all goes well!  I also wanted to mention the very important need for teens BOYS and young 20's BOYS to do self exam for testicular cancer.  My friend who is a nurse had told her teenage son all about testicular cancer.  Lo and behold he felt something when in the shower and called her.  He was off at college--she told him to get on the next plane and fly home.  He was looked at right away--and he DID have testicular cancer (caught SOOOooo early that he is FINE! Yea!)  I sat down my teenage son at the time and all his soccer team buddies that were over at the house and gave them my big, passionate lecture about watching out for testicular cancer.  That was several years ago, and to this day those beautiful young guys tease me about the day I got so adamant about checking themselves out.  But anything to raise awareness.  So, not only should teen girls do self exams--so should teen boys.  I bet your dear daughter will be just fine--she's been through more than her share of "young" illness.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer in Teens

Posts.Content: Absollutely!  Why? #1 YOUR anxiety!   When they found my lump I was frantic to "GET IT OUT!"  That was a Wednesday afternoon and I had the lumpectomy on Friday morning.  My long-time doctor was more than willing to get things moving for me...and that gave me a lot of comfort.   I am 4 yrs. out now--only had radiation and 4 yrs. of Tamoxifen.  I believe we MUST be proactive about our health.  Granted, you may not be able to move things up...but of course you can voice your concern--I always say, a patient IS a CUSTOMER in one sense.  I wish you luck in your endeavor to take care of that "BEAN."
Posts.Title: How soon should I see a Dr?

Posts.Content: I am a staunch advocate of breast cancer awareness.  I am a survivor--was diagnosed in July 04.  Absolutely, I would love to participate in your study: --Message edited by CancerCompass staff. For personal protection, email address removed. Consider private reply. Please review CancerCompass Member Guidelines at http://www.cancercompass.com/common/guidelines.html--
Posts.Title: Looking for volunteers to share their experiences

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed w. very early breast cancer in July 2004. Only had radiation via mammocite (internal direct hit to shere the tumor WAS). Went on tamoxifen in August '04. I really haven't noticed anything different about my hair. In fact, i have it colored regularly--no problem. Quite frankly, I had not even heard that Tamoxifen could be a problem w. hair. I guess ignorance is sometimes bliss. If you notice thinning, though, I would talk to your hairdresser about the dangers of coloring or perming! You'll be beautiful even w. thin hair because YOU are a SURVIVOR!
Posts.Title: question about a medicine..

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed w. very early breast cancer in July 2004. Only had radiation via mammocite (internal direct hit to shere the tumor WAS). Went on tamoxifen in August '04. I really haven't noticed anything different about my hair. In fact, i have it colored regularly--no problem. Quite frankly, I had not even heard that Tamoxifen could be a problem w. hair. I guess ignorance is sometimes bliss. If you notice thinning, though, I would talk to your hairdresser about the dangers of coloring or perming! You'll be beautiful even w. thin hair because YOU are a SURVIVOR!
Posts.Title: question about a medicine..

Posts.Content: I hope one of the health care folks on this site will respond to the question of whether or not black kohosh is safe for estrogen receptive/tamolifen--please answer docs or nurse!  I too would like to try this IF it is safe.
Posts.Title: Black Cohosh

Posts.Content: Thoughts from a survivor (diagnosed in July 2004) who is doing great and is a true activist when it comes to women's health! It is only natural that you are beside yourself with fear and anxiety.  But what you may not know is that the odds are you are not malignant; however, if you are?  Well, it is just amazing the advances in medicine.  You don't really know about the incredible success rate of surviving breast cancer until you have been in the dark, murky pool called "Cancer."  One thing I have learned is that "It is what it is" and that "you just do what you have to do."  Try not to awfulize.  Dig down deep into yourself and you'll find strength and courage and a knowledge that you WILL get through whatever this is!
Posts.Title: my doctor found two tumors

Posts.Content: I wonder if you have an unusually low pain tolerance.  Your case sounds SO extreme to me.  You need to hang in there--I think your fear and anxiety may be in overdrive (which is totally understandable).  You are at a very vulnerable time right now.  The really important thing is to do absolutely whatever is necessary to have the best, successful treatment for breast cancer.  That must be your goal.  But do speak up when you think health care people are not "listening" to you.  Afterall, YOU are the "customer" and it's YOUR life.  Best of luck---from a survivor (diagnosed in July 2004).
Posts.Title: Coping with fear and anxiety

Posts.Content: Check out your medication on www.askapatient  Good Site!  People rate drugs and talk about their side effects.  Definitely worth a look!  Lots of luck to you.  Stay on top of what is good for you and how you feel!
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia

Posts.Content: I am writing in response to a discussion I read concerning topical treatments for fragile, dry vaginal tissue.  I am post breast cancer and post menopause (age 59).  My oncologist and my GP doc both have told me that using PREMARIN cream is okay and safe for me to use.  I find I need it almost daily on my outer area of the vaginal opening.  Sometimes it hurts just to use toilet paper.  I must say, however, that it just worries me to use a cream with chemical estrogen since my tumor was estrogen positive.  Do any of you out there have an opinion?  (I go see my doc, who feels that I am safe, in a couple of weeks and want some info to carry in).  I will try the flax seed oil recommended by Tre.  However, I do question adding in vaseline.  When I have used Vaseline to get some relief, I have ended up with a bladder infection.  I know a lot of women have this problem--and it is SO frustrating.  Yes, it can be painful to sit and walk, and it has been at times excrutiating to have intimacy w. my husband.  I don't want to give up the "intimate" side of my life.
Posts.Title: Topical Estrogen

Posts.Content: I know people meant well and were dear, dear friends---but---when people came by after my lumpectomy with food, flowers, etc. they would stay and stay to visit.  I was SOOOOOO exhausted.  Sometimes it was hard to make conversation I was so tired, sleepy.  a few times when the doorbell would ring my husband simply had to tell them I was sleeping.  And there were times when I felt like I looked just awful---I was self conscious about my exhausted, no make-up appearance.  Just be aware of things like this.  So glad you are there for her!  Sharing a quote that I think is appropriate for you and your sister:  The I in illness is isolation, and the crucial letters in wellness are WE.
Posts.Title: Hw can I help?

Posts.Content: On 2/18/2007 Hana24 wrote: My mom b/c came back and so she has to take chemo and radiation again but my concern is that i dont think her body can handle it because of her body weight. She is 5 ft nothing and now weights 89lbs. She doesnt look healthy. My familly and I have been tring foods that are good for her but she wont eat?  All she eats everyonce in awhile is bread. Does anyone have any advise? Thanks Hana
Posts.Title: Loss of appetite

Posts.Content: One lesson I have learned: don't start taking 2 new drugs at the same time. I started Forteo for osteoporosis and aromasin in August. I have had terrible joint pain and swelling of hands and feet. I have read on the message board of other women having terrible pain with aromasin & arimedix. The description of side effects matched mine. My dr. has told me to go back to tamoxifen. Now I have read after searching and searching tht Forteo can cause arthralgia (joint pain) but it is not common. I do not know which medication is really causing the problem. Maybe both are since some days I literally can hardly move! I am an avid exerciser--walk 3 miles a day (try to). Is anyone out there taking both of these drugs together? Or has anyone had bad expereince with Forteo? Kittycath
Posts.Title: Aromasin & Forteo

Posts.Content: Are these 2 drugs the same thing---just different brands? I took tamoxafin for 2 yers and now am on aromasin. The side effect of joint pain is just miserable. Does anyone think taking tamoxafin for all 5 yrs. is just as good? I see my oncologist in mid-november and will talk to him about it.
Posts.Title: Refusing Arimidex

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in July '06.  I had twice daily radiation for 5 days via the mammocite device.  I thought it was convenient and I got the radiation over FAST.  It will be exhausting, though.  Rest, sleep, rest, sleep during the time you are having this done. I thought my mammocite was very successful.  I will say it "smarted" when they took it all out--but, hey, we survivors get tough to pain!  Good luck with your mammocite.
Posts.Title: mammosite

Posts.Content: Oh my gosh YES!  Particularly since you are SO YOUNG.  You have so much life ahead of you.  You will just look back on all this someday--be amazed and proud--will be stronger emotionally, spirituallly, and physically.  Don't chance not doing all you can do!  Surround yourself with supportive people.  Your cancer center people that do the chemo and radiation WILL BE WONDERFUL!!!!!  I volunteer every week at the center--love it!  I'm a breast cancer survivor 3 yrs. out.  I want you to be a survivor too!
Posts.Title: chemo or no chemo?

Posts.Content: On August 23 I will take my last tamoxifen pill.  By the way, we are having a PINK PARTY--everyone is wearing pink--the final pill is going to be on a silver platter--and I am going to down it with PINK champagne.  Here is my concern:  I actually have a bit of fear about NOT taking it anymore.  I feel like I am losing my shield, my protection.  I was diagnosed in 04--caught very early, lumpectomy, very small tumor, no lymphs involved, had 10 radiation treatments, and then I started tamoxifen.  After visiting with my oncologist and asking him what was so magic about FIVE years, he talked about how studies show that that is the time for mazimum benefit.  But in my case, FOUR years would definitely be adequate.  I am going to send out invitations to the party soon.  Can anybody give me some peace of mind about all this ???
Posts.Title: My final Tamox. pill

Posts.Content: I totally agree with everything Tree had to say (she is THE guru on this site).  I will throw in my experience and ideas.  I needed the support of others when I had my biopsy and diagnosis (July 2004).  But at times I was overwhelmed by the attention--and simply wanted to be alone.  I found that often trying to be "cheery"  and make conversation was exhausting.  It all comes down to how close your relationship is with the person.  Do you know her well enough to pick up the signs that she IS exhausted, either physically or emotionally?  I am a "card sender."  It is a passion of mine to try to "touch someone" by sending them just a little note that says, "I am thinking about you; I care about you."  I also love to include a little quote.  I make little magnets with quotes that I send to people and provide at the local Cancer Center.  My little magnet quotes are often put on patients' trays when they are getting lunch while receiving chemo.  There has been a great response to these little thoughts.  When you cannot be with your friend, particularly after you return home, do make it a habit to just send a little note.  I think everyone loves to get mail.  All the cards I got during my surgeries--well, I would just read them over and over.  And Now--4 1/2 years later--I can revisit all the wonderful sentiments.  Sharing a quote with you:  "Become a possibilitarian.  No matter how dark things seem to be or actually are, raise your sights and see possibilities--always see them, for they're always there."
Posts.Title: when does patient need physical help?

Posts.Content: I began Tamoxifen in Aug. 2004.  I asked my onc. about the "new" drugs aromasin and arimadex in '06 and wondered if I should change to them.  He said I could certainly try it--I started aromasin in Aug. '06.  No obvious side effects for a while and then the joint pain started and just got worse and worse.  It was horrible trying to get up in the morning.  By Oct. I could not stand it any longer and went back on Tamoxifen.  My advice--try it--you may be one of the lucky ones.  But REALLY monitor yourself--actually keep a log of things you notice.  If you get the incridible joint pain, a record would be really helpful for you and the doctor to make a decision.  Also, how "bad" was your cancer (ALL cancer is bad, right?). My cancer was caught VERY early--no chemo--only 10 radiation treatments...doc said I can even now stop my Tamox.  I take my last pill August 23--served on a silver platter and swallowed with pink champagne at my PINK party.  Good luck on your jouorney with meds!
Posts.Title: positive feedback on aromasin

Posts.Content: I was nice to hear someone who is about my same age (56) have the same problems. I started Aromasin and FORTEO (injection medication for bone density) at the same time. I went from actonel to forteo. After reading on this site--I am now sure my joint pain is from aromasin. I find it agonizing to get up and walk in the morning. After a couple of hours the pain seems to go away. Just MOVING seems to help! I have always been an avid exerciser and still walk 3 miles or work out everyday in the afternoon. Have you found it to make any difference to take the Aromasin in the MORNING vs. the EVENING? I am seeing my oncologist for my 6-month check-up Nov. 20. I would ceertainly like to go back to tamoxafin if possible. I will take the hot flashes over these body aches and pains. And, yes, I think the pain is getting worse and more annoying. The Aromasin written insert said few experienced joint pain and it often goes away after taking aromasin for a few weeks or months. I think that is baloney! I have been on aromsin since July. I had a very early stage breast cancer in July 2004 and only had direct radiation (mamacite)--10 tratments and no chemo. I do wonder if these side effects of Aromasin are really worth and is it really necessary to switch to it?
Posts.Title: Aromasin/joint Pain

Posts.Content: It is worse to be told that "it may be serious" or We're not sure about the abnormality we see."  Then you really get consumed and awfulize and go nuts!  My lump was taken out in July 04.  When I went back a yr. later for my post-cancer mammogram, they scared me to death pointing out an area that looked "different."  Alas, it was nothing but scar tissue from the surgery. And the scar tissue continues to harden and develop a bit as time passes.  My point?  I bet your worry IS scar tissue!  The waiting to know is the worst part--truly!  Hang in there--ultimately you will be fine!
Posts.Title: Confused

Posts.Content: It sounds to me like there is an obvious lack of communication here!!!  I don't understand why you aren't being given meds for SIDE EFFECTS.  I know you are attached to your doctors--so am I.  But a second opinion might be in order.  Actually, you are asking for second opinions on this forum.  I tell so many people that they MUST be proactive about their health.  Well, you ARE!  You have to keep in there--reading, researching, paying close attention to your body's responses, etc.  Try talking to your Dr. again with a list of written down questions.  I find that when I go in with a written list I have a much more successful Dr. visit and get more "action" --and attention, for that matter.  Good Luck on your road to good health!  P.S. I just wrote in about taking my last tamox. pill--have you got an opinion on my concerns????
Posts.Title: breast cancer and colon cancer Dr abandonement

Posts.Content: Oh my--how absolutely wonderful and blessed you are to have such an endearing relationship with your sister. Be sure she knows this and hears it from you often--just how important she is to you and all your family.  When I went through my breast cancer ordeal in 2004, I longed to hear more CARE from my family.  They may have felt a great deal for me--but they needed to express it.  Cancer's victim needs to HEAR--over and over again--that they do indeed really matter.  I want to share some of my favorite quotes with you:  Too often we underestimate the power of a touch, a smile, a kind word, a listening ear, and honest compliment, or the smallest act of caring, all of which have the potential to turn a life around.--Leo Buscaglia Courage is being scared to death and saddling up anyway.--John Wayne Sisters function as safety nets in a chaotic world simply by being there for each other.--Carol Saline
Posts.Title: at the end of day

Posts.Content: I have read the above entries and they contain EXCELLENT advice.  I want to throw in my 2-cents worth.  I am a breast cancer survivor, age 58 (diag. 2004).  I've raised 2 fabulous children. Not a grandmother yet--but I will be a good one too someday. I am also the director of a wonderful preschool.  I do a LOT of parent counseling...working with today's generation of parents whose lack of parenting skills is often appalling.  I deal with what I call "helicopter parents"---they continuously "hover" over their children--doing more harm than good.  When parents are SOOOO protective, a negative message is often relayed to the child resulting in the child being insecure.  When well-meaning parents rush to the rescue, the message to the child is: "I'm not sure I trust you to succeed." I do believe your grandson's parents fit into this category.  I highly recommend you tracking down the article, THE PERFECT CHILDHOOD: Why It's Bad for Kids by Judsen Culbreth.  This was printed in Sept. 2005 Readers' Digest.  At my school we give copies of this article to parents of our 3's and 4's.  I also have a suggestion for YOUR coping of this situation of this situation.  Obviously you like to write and are good at expressing your thoughts and feelings.  I LOVE to write.  I suggest you keep a journal (a nice, pretty bound book) and write in it everyday or whenever you feel the need.  Direct your writing TO your grandchild...tell him about YOUR life, your values, your suggestions for living a good life, your feelings of love for him.  Hopefully, this journal will be written over many years...you may even need to go to a second bound book.  By the way--do date your entries.  Can you just imagine what a treasure this "diary" would be to your grandson someday???  What a beautiful piece of you he would have forever.  I have letters written to me by my grandmother who has been gone for 30+ years...I love looking at her handwriting; I love touching her loving words on the page.  Words spoken drift in the wind, but words written become a testimony that last forever and can be treasured and give someone strength.  I am imagining your grandson reading your advice, etc. when he is a teenager--a grown man--and a father himself someday.  What a gift!  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: grandson is my best chemo medicine

Posts.Content: I am just chiming in with everybody else!  Do NOT let doctors intimidate you.  Make demands--you are not only the patient but also the CUSTOMER.  When my little breast lump was felt by my doc during my yearly pap smear, I just KNEW it wasn't going to be good news.  I read and researched.  When I was told by my doc, "I don't think it looks good," that was on a Wednesday and through my insistence, I had surgery on that Friday.  (I am 4 years out now and doing GREAT).  Be brave and speak up!  Lots of luck to you!  Sharin my favorite quote:  Courage is being scared to death and saddling up anyway. (John Wayne)
Posts.Title: After 36 years, I'm worried again

Posts.Content: Hooray for you!!!  I am right there with you.  I LOVE to collect PINK stuff.  And I amazed at how many people see something PINK and think of me and treat me with the little item they found.  It may be a pencil or a notepad or a magnet--but how I embrace their thoughtfulness!  It being October (the PINK month) I am thrilled to be speaking at my local Cancer Center about my journey.  And I have collecting all sorts of PINK doodads to use as party favors and doorprizes.  Of course I am looking around for stuff, but I am so tickled PINK to see how breast cancer stuff is just everywhere and incorporated in so many things---like golf clubs!  That is cool--who would have thought.  We ARE going to whoop this disease someday and someday SOON!  I have shared this story before on this site, but I will do so again. I think it is VERY important to celebrate milestones in one's journey with breast cancer.  I took my last Tamoxifen on Aug. 23.  With family and friends (about 60 people) we had a PINK party.  Beautiful invitations were sent out.  (And people did not want to miss this--what a crowd). The home was decorated with PINK roses and PINK napkins, cloths, plates, etc.  Everyone was encouraged to wear PINK.  That in particular made the party awesome.  Men went out and bought PINK shirts.  Every shade of PINK was there.  Cute little girls had on their hot PINK. The menu was desserts and PINK champagne--perfect for a beautiful summer evening (8:00 pm). The array of desserts were PINK: PINK cake baked in a breast cancer ribbon pan, ribbon-shaped cookies, PINK candies.  Everyone was wanting to make and bring a PINK dessert to the party.  At the party everyone cheered and toasted me when I had my last pill served on a silver platter and downed it with a glass of PINK champagne.  There was laughter; there were tears; there was an electric emotion that was almost touchable.  I have a special cookie bar that I have made for years called Survivor Bars.  I baked them, put them in little PINK boxes, and they made a terrific party favor.  I cannot tell you what a wonderful time this was!  People are still talking about the PINK party.  Not only was it a great celebration for me, but what a way to spread breast cancer awareness.  I encourage all women to celebrate the events in their journey--whether it is the completion of radiation or chemo or successful surgery--whatever!  Truly--adversity CAN be turned into a positive.  It may look impossible to some, but dig deep, celebrate your life right NOW!
Posts.Title: Soaking up life - the cancer survivor way

Posts.Content: Do listen to the medical response.  The very fact that you are worried about enough to write in on this message board proves that you need to get some peace of mind.  It's the not knowing and "awfulizing" that can just turn you inside out.  Get checked----soon!  A survivor who so firmly believes that you MUST be proactive.
Posts.Title: Is this ok?

Posts.Content: On 1/31/2007 Kimarie wrote: I am probably making a mistake but I quit taking femara last night.  I am going back on tamoxifin.  But if I dont start feeling like my old self, I will probably quit that too.  I want to feel normal again.  I want to lose this added weight.  I dont like feeling depressed and angry and on the edge.  I just want to go back to a normal life. Kimarie
Posts.Title: I have decided to Quit Drugs

Posts.Content: Radiation is the usual follow-up after chemo.  What are you really afraid of?  Goodness, you have endured chemo which I am sure must be worse.  Research, ask questions, get several opinions, and just be proactive about your health.  I had 10 radiation treatments via a mammocite device--a tube with a little balloon on the end was inserted directly where the tumor was removed (behind the nipple).  A little seed of radiation traveled through the tube and got in there and "blasted" the area for a few seconds.  This was done morning and afternoon for 5 consecutive days.  It was exhausting--I slept a LOT.  But--it wasn't painful or horrible.  Look at all your options.  Take care!
Posts.Title: Radiation - the decision to do or not

Posts.Content: Stge 0 with radiation doesn't mean a whole lot of treatment necessarily.  In 220 I was diag. with stage 0/no nodes/all contained.  They put in a mammocite device for my radiation---that is a direct hit to the tumor site through a tube and balloon thing.  I had 2 treatments a day for 10 days.  Now I am on Tamoxifen.  Talk to your Dr. about the mammocite.
Posts.Title: Lumpectamy or Mastectomy? HELP!

Posts.Content: If you have read this message board a lot, you have notice the huge number of messages dealing with these 2 drugs.  I think the majority of women have some side effects--many severe.  Of course, those that are happy as can be with the drug are not writing in about it.  I was on tamoxifen for 2 yrs., asked the doctor about trying one of these drugs since I had read about them, and he said, well, let's try it.  I thought the joint pain was SO debilitating!  After about 3 months I went back to the tamoxifen and just toook my last one Aug. 23.  I do have a friend who was right away put on Aromasin and never did have the tamoxifen.  She has not noticed any side effects (she's been using it about a yr.).  She is indeed one of the lucky ones.  My advice?  Golly, if it is causing such intolerable side effects, talk to your Dr. about what else is out there--what else can we try to help deal with the side effects?  It's your body and your reactions and your instincts.  Keep being proactive.  Try www.askapatient to read about others' experiences with these drugs.  Best of luck to you.  Sharing a thought for your day:  There is in every true woman's heart a spark of heavenly fire, which lies dormant in the broad daylight of prosperity; but which kindles up and beams and blazes in the dark hour of adversity. (Washington Irving)
Posts.Title: Arimidex versus Aromasin

Posts.Content: I have a friend who is one year ahead of me with almost the exact same breast cancer history.  She was diag. in 03; me in 04. She has just found out that she must have a hysterectomy due to a "bad" pap.  I also know that Tamoxifen has a slight percentage to cause uterine dysplasia (pre- cancerous cells). Can anyone provide feedback on the RISKS of taking Tamoxifen.  I'm worried since I have all my female parts!
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen effects on uterus

Posts.Content: You don't need to be ASKING anything--I think you just want people who have walked in your shoes to listen--because nobody, NOBODY, knows what this is like-- to go down this path of chemo, cancer, radiation, stages, fear, anxiety, hope, and on and on.  Please know that me, and many others, hope FOR you and hope WITH you.  Be ever so grateful you are feeling so well with this oral chemo. Gather those precious grandchildren around.  Children can bring joy, respite, distraction, hope, and laughter like nothing else.  Best of luck with your journey--I hope you will soon begin to see a light at the end of your personal tunnel.
Posts.Title: stage 4

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in July 2004--very early--not in lymphs--no chemo--only radiation.  I took tamoxifen from July 2004 until July 2006.  My doctor put me on aromasin (the usual protocol, I am told).  I HATED the aromasin--I have NEVER experienced such joint pain, swelling, fatigue.  I told the doctor about and he put me back on tamoxifen.  I got the feeling that it really wasn't all that necessary to be on Aromasin--tamoxifen is adequate.  Then I have read differenct things on the internet that scare me--aromsin and arimadex are important to take after using tamoxifen for a while.  Golly, I hope I am not doing something stupid.  Does anyone out there feel totally comfortable just sticking with tamoxifen????
Posts.Title: Aromasin pain

Posts.Content: There is nothing like we cancer survivor gals interacting.  I have been with this site now for a while--I have really learned a LOT.  So many of us feel the same emotions, the same fears, the same confusion, the same depression--and so on and so on.  So, dear "boobie princess" you aare NOT alone.  You will find you have many loyal "subject" on this site.  I was diag. in July 2004...have been on tamoxifen 3 yrs.  Just saw my oncologist TODAY--I am doing great; everything is clear.  On ething that caught my attention in your message was your insomnia.  I have suffered horribly wioth insomnia all my life.  I so freeked when I was diagnosed with breast cancer that I went on Effexor (helps tamoxifen hot flashes and modd), and I take Klonopin for anxiety.  I could care less if I end up addicted to Klonopin.  Since taking a small dose every night for 3 yrs. I sleep like a baby which makes me less tired, healthier, etc.  I have had ONLY 1 slight cold since breast cancer in 04.  I owe it to a good night's sleep--and being more attentive to myself (diet and exercise).  Anyway, you might want to look into getting something to help you with the insomnia.  Sleeping at night has made me a NEW person.  So, dear princess, welcome to the club.  We are all here for ya.  Love to you.
Posts.Title: Reaching out

Posts.Content: Bless your heart!  You are not in a battle; you are in a war!  But you sound like quite a fighter.  I want to comment on the aromasin.  I, too, had horrible side effects.  After 4 months and after consulting with my doc, I stopped the medication just cold turkey--no gradual thing.  In about 2 weeks all the joint pain did indeed fade!  I had no "withdrawal."  I hope both you and your husband have a good support system.  Writing on this site can be very calming, encouraging, and give you solace.  Please know my thoughts are with you.  Stay proactive about your health.  Follow your gut instinct and "demand" action from your doctors.  So often what we THINK and FEEL about our health can be quite accurate.  Love to you both.
Posts.Title: Third bout with breast cancer since 1995

Posts.Content: Well, you need to learn all you can.  Be PROACTIVE concerning your treatments.  This site is GREAT!  I too had a small lump, no nodes problem, and only had twice-a-day radiation via the mammocite for 5 days  (August '06).  For me radiation was just exhausting.  Just clear your calendar--let yourself just BE!  I would come home from A.M. treatment and nap until the P.M. treatment.  I also went to bed early.  Tell everyone not to make demands on you during this time.  I look back and I tried to do too much.  You mention you don't want to take Aromasin...believe me, I understand.  I took Tamoxifen 3 yrs.--tried Aromasin for 41/2 months and went back to Tamoxifen.  My Dr. assured me I am safe to stick with Tamoxifen.  I cannot give any advice about foods or anything during radiation--just sleep, sleep, sleep!
Posts.Title: post surgery lumpectomy pre radiation

Posts.Content: Pay really close attention to those side effects--you may want to even journal them daily.  If you find it to be just unbearable, you will then have some good data to share with your doctor.  I was on Aromasin for about 6 to 8 weeks about a year ago.  My ahces in my hands and feet (particularly when getting up in the morning) were just shocking to me.  I felt like I was 150 yrs. old.  It did not get better for me and my doc put me back on the tamoxifen---which on Aug. 9th I will take my last tamoxifen pill.  BUT----there many on this site that have said that they had no side effects from the inhibitors.  Isn't it curious how the human back can react in so many different ways.  Each one of us is definitely unique!
Posts.Title: Thanks

Posts.Content: What a lovely tribute you wrote about your friend, Laura.  I must comment on the beautiful words and thoughts of her 17-yr. old son.  It was so moving to read, particularly with Mother's Day this Sunday.  How blessed he is to have you to "mother" him.  After reading your letter he is truly blessed and will live up to all his mother's expectations through your guidance and love.      Thoughts from a survivor
Posts.Title: Laura passed away on Saturday

Posts.Content: I LOVE to collect PINK stuff.  And I amazed at how many people see something PINK and think of me and treat me with the little item they found.  It may be a pencil or a notepad or a magnet--but how I embrace their thoughtfulness!  It being October (the PINK month) I am thrilled to be speaking at my local Cancer Center about my journey.  And I have collecting all sorts of PINK doodads to use as party favors and doorprizes.  Of course I am looking around for stuff, but I am so tickled PINK to see how breast cancer stuff is just everywhere and incorporated in so many things---like golf clubs!  That is cool--who would have thought.  We ARE going to whoop this disease someday and someday SOON!  I have shared this story before on this site, but I will do so again. I think it is VERY important to celebrate milestones in one's journey with breast cancer.  I took my last Tamoxifen on Aug. 23.  With family and friends (about 60 people) we had a PINK party.  Beautiful invitations were sent out.  (And people did not want to miss this--what a crowd). The home was decorated with PINK roses and PINK napkins, cloths, plates, etc.  Everyone was encouraged to wear PINK.  That in particular made the party awesome.  Men went out and bought PINK shirts.  Every shade of PINK was there.  Cute little girls had on their hot PINK. The menu was desserts and PINK champagne and PINK lemonade--perfect for a beautiful summer evening (8:00 pm). The array of desserts were PINK: PINK cake baked in a breast cancer ribbon pan, ribbon-shaped cookies, PINK candies.  Everyone was wanting to make and bring a PINK dessert to the party.  At the party everyone cheered and toasted me when I had my last pill served on a silver platter and downed it with a glass of PINK champagne.  There was laughter; there were tears; there was an electric emotion that was almost touchable.  I have a special cookie bar that I have made for years called Survivor Bars.  I baked them, put them in little PINK boxes, and they made a terrific party favor.  I cannot tell you what a wonderful time this was!  People are still talking about the PINK party.  Not only was it a great celebration for me, but what a way to spread breast cancer awareness.  I encourage all women to celebrate the events in their journey--whether it is the completion of radiation or chemo or successful surgery--whatever!  Truly--adversity CAN be turned into a positive.  It may look impossible to some, but dig deep, celebrate your life right NOW!
Posts.Title: Have a PINK party

Posts.Content: On 2/20/2007 Kimberly M. wrote:   On 2/15/2007 Suzq53 wrote: Hi. I am five years out, as of Jan 14th. I took tamoxifin for two years, then switched to aromasin. I was told that I would be on these drugs for a total of five years. Now, my doctor tells me that I can stay on Aromosin for five years. I'm concerned that maybe these drugs might be doing harm that we don't know about - but at the same time I want to do all I can to prevent the big C from returning. I have had joint aches, back pain, sadness (on and off), tiredness and just not feeling "good" since going through this cancer experience (chemo, radiation). I'm curious if some of these feelings will go away if I stop taking the aromosin. I don't know what to do -- keep taking it, or stop. Any thoughts? My heart-felt wishes go out to all of you on this message board. Thanks for reading my message and for your thoughs. Hi,  I am 4 yrs out and after taking tamoxifin for 3.5 yrs I was put on Arimidex, bad side effects for me so was changed to Aromasin.  I experienced the same side effects that you are discribing and my Oncologist took me off of that too and back on Tamoxifin (he says for 1 yr).  I feel ten times better than when on Aromasin.  I hope you find the answers you are looking for and hope you are feeling better soon.
Posts.Title: Should I keep taking Aromosin?

Posts.Content: I too will chime in about this medication.  Every side effect you have I also had--over about a 4-month prd.  My doc switched me back to tamoxifen.  I just respended to another inquiry about this medication...read on down a bit on the list.  The most important thing about talking to your doctor about your symptoms and problems is to be proactive, informed and knowledgeable.  My son is in medical school, and I so hope me sharing with him all the frustrations with doctors I read about will make HIM a better doc someday.  Go to the site www.askapatient and type in your medication.  It's a great site--direct from patients with no bias that you get from going to a drug company's site.
Posts.Title: Adjunct therapy

Posts.Content: I am 57--diagnosed with estro receptive breast cancer in July 04--lumpectomy & radiation (No chemo)--have been on tamoxifen since--tried aromasin for 4 months: horrible.  I read all the time about breast cancer.  I do know I have read the following often: a breast that is tender and sore usually has a cyst in that area.  Did my breast have any tenderness, soreness when diagnosed with Br. C?? Absolutely not.  I was dumbfounded when my Dr. of over 20 yrs. was doing my yearly pap, checking me out, and said, "Have you ever felt this?"  Even when she put my fingers there I STILL could not feel it.  Yes, my breast cancer was totally silent.
Posts.Title: I am 58. My breast hurt all the time....

Posts.Content: I truly hope you have access to other treatment facilities and/or doctors.  I find it SO unbelievable that docs can get so jaded that they can be what APPEARS to be heartless. When you are going through any kind of cancer scare, treatment, diagnosis, etc., it really is like you are the only person ever to have such hysterical and frustrating feelings.  I think it is imperative that you get connected to medical caregivers that can make you feel confident and with whom you can entrust your LIFE!!!  Please, find peace by getting a second opinion.  Be proactive.  Ask questions--in fact, write them down and take your list in at every visit...I always do.  My doctors appreciate it.  They really do.  Have someone with you (friend or family) that can look at how you are being treated a little more objectively than maybe you can.  Sharing a quote: Always direct your thoughts to those truths that will give you confidence, hope, joy, and love.  Turn your mind away from those that inspire you with fear, sadness, and depression.
Posts.Title: prone 16 day treatment after effects

Posts.Content: Check out the site www.askapatient.com  because it is a great site to read about what others are experiencing about a particular drug.  I have found it to be very helpful. (There are no drug companies involved pushing their own drug.)
Posts.Title: Temodar and leg pain???

Posts.Content: Oh my, can't life just be unbearable at times?  I want to share some of my favorite quotes that may help you cope: Hard things are put in our way, not to stop us, but to call out our courage and strength. You gain strength, courage and confidence by every experience in which you really stop to look fear in the face. You are able to say to yourself, "I lived through this horror. I can take the next thing that comes along." . . . You must do the thing you think you cannot do. — Eleanor Roosevelt
Posts.Title: Spreading too fast

Posts.Content: I just saw my oncologist TODAY (love him--he is great).  I was diag. in July 04...been on tamoxifen 3 yrs. w. 2 more to go.  I tried Aromsin--the joint pain was ridiculous!  I asked him today if I am ok staying on tamox for the next 2 years.  He says YES and not to worry about needing to try arimadex.  Tamox. has been shown (small %) to cause precancerous or cancer in the uterus.  If you don't have a uterus--no problem!  I still have all my female parts.  I am just being sure I get a PAP and also an endometrial biopsy just to watch the uterus.  Do NOT be afraid to talk openly and frankly with your Dr. about your medications.  It it YOUR body!  If you try another medicine and it works for a while and then the joint pain begins, act on it.  Please don't sit back and try to be brave.  You are being proactive about your body by just participating in this site (which is GREAT--you will learn a LOT).  So, today I am thrillled: mammo was perfectly clear, pap was totally normal, and I am haaving the uterine biopsy next week.  I feel good about bring up the biopsy and asking for it!  So, stick with staying in tune to you body.  But I have learned we cancer survivors always stay a little bit scared!
Posts.Title: Introduction to the board

Posts.Content: I am a survivor--diagnosed in 2004--had radiation but no chemo.  I just turned 59.  I have learned in my volunteer work with breast cancer victims that everyone reacts to the BIG C differently.  Some want LOTS of people; lots of comjmunication; lots of contact.  Some need to back away from society for a while.  I went through a mixture of both emotions.  My suggestion is to send cards often--or emails.  That way your friend knows you are thinking of her without you getting in touch with her during a "leave-me-alone" period.  Just follow her lead--but DO something.  Someone who you EXPECT will be there and isn't is so very ,very hurtful.  She is lucky to have a firend like you.
Posts.Title: Survivors

Posts.Content: Thought I would write again--am anxious to get some opinions.  My Dr. & I discussed ending my tamoxifen regime after FOUR yrs. rather than 5.  This is due to my "mild" case of breast cancer (is there such a thing, ha!). He said I would not be putting myself in jeapordy to stop medication after 4 yrs.  Diagnosed in 04, estrogren receptive, lumpectomy, caught very early, no chemo, 10 radiation treatments.  I have been excited to stop--now I am getting scared to.  Aug. 23 is my last day--we are planning a PINK party. Any advice out there?
Posts.Title: tamoxifen for only FOUR yrs???

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with breast cancer in July 2004: very early, only had to have radiation via the mamocite.  In july 06 my Dr. put me on Aromasin.  At the same time I started Forteo (for bone density).  TIP: Do not EVER start to prescriptions at the same time--you cannot figure out which one is giving you the side effects.  I think I got a double jolt of joint pain from BOTH drugs.  I felt like I was 110 (I'm 57) and I could barely walk in the morning. It just got worse and worse!  In Nov. my Dr. put me back on Tamoxifen and I stopped the Forteo and went back to ACTONEL for bone density.  It really took about a month, but all joint pain and achey everywhere disappeared.  I have worried, however, that NOT taking the aromasin make me "susceptible."  My Dr. says it's not that important to change to aromasin--tamoxifen is just fine.  Some of the reading I have done makes me wonder.  Also, ALL mammograms and blood test since 04 have been totally clear.  Just want to know if some of you have encountered going BACK to tamoxifen and how you feel about it.
Posts.Title: back to Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: You definitely need peace of mind.  But, oh my, how easy we fall into awfulizing and imagining the worst-case scenario.  I hope your visit went well and ALL is well.  Write back.  If you are needing more follow-up, be proactive, ask lots of questions (write them down--take them to your visit).  Have a loved one, friend, or family go with you.  You need someone who can concentrate on the discussion probably a little better than you can--fear has its way of making us "lose our hearing."  Sharing a quote: Always direct your thoughts to those truths that will give you confidence, hope, joy, and love.  Turn your mind away from those that inspire you with fear, sadness, and depression.
Posts.Title: Scared I might be developing breast cancer

Posts.Content: Are these really 2 different drugs? I thought they were the same---just different brnd names. I have been on Aromsin since July---terrible joint pain!!!! But I have read on the message board that Arimidex can have the same terrible side effect? I see my oncologist Nov. 20--before I ask him about switching---I just want some thoughts of others. Kittycath
Posts.Title: Arimidex Verses Aromasin? Help me Rhonda!

Posts.Content: I had the mamosite  utilized for my radiation in August of 2004.  I was VERY PLEASED with the experience...well, as pleased as one can get when you are dealing with radiation for breast cancer.  I was estrogen positive, 1.5 mm tumor with clean margins, and no lymphs involved.  I was also told that being small breasted was a help with the mammosite procedure. The advantage is that you are radiated only in the exact spot!  I think that is safe and also HEALTHY areas of your body are not being radiated.  It was very fascinating to watch the little "seed" of radiation travel through the tube and be "in there" for an exact, specific abount of time.  Example: sometimes it would be in there for 2 min. and 5 seconds or 6 minutes and 2.5 seconds, etc.  Every time you go for the treatment the breast is x-rayed to see that the balloon has not deflated or shifted.  My little balloon was always just where it should be.  The balloon stays inflated for the whole 5 days and is about the size of a ping pong ball.  Also, at least in 2004, the radiation had to be twice a day with a certain amount of hours between "zaps," and it had to be 5 consecutive days.  So, look for being scheduled for a Monday through Friday. The technician told me I would feel very fatigued.  WOW! did I????  I don't know if it is because the radiation is a "real whammy" via the mammosite, but I was exhausted.  I would get back into bed immediately after the morning treatment and sleep until the afternoon treatment.  I would also go to bed about 8 pm. I also felt tired for several week after the treatment was completed...usually going to bed about 8;30.  All in all, I say this is the way to go if you can.  It is so wonderful how all these breast cancer treatments are advancing!  I am now a true survivor.  I took my last tamoxifen on Aug. 23.  I now get a cancer check-up (blood work) every 6 months, and I am getting a mammogram just once a year like any other gal!  Best of luck to you!  Sharing one of my favorite quotes: Courage is being scared to death and saddling up anyway. (John Wayne)
Posts.Title: One week radiation tx
